name: J Gunn
comment info:
We found R0 is likely to be 5.7 given our current state of knowledge, with a broad 95% CI (3.8–8.9). Among many factors, the lack of awareness of this new pathogen and the Lunar New Year travel and gathering in early and mid-January 2020 might or might not play a role in the high R0. A recent study based on structural analysis of the virus particles suggests SARS-CoV-2 has a much higher affinity to the receptor needed for cell entry than the 2003 SARS virus (21), providing a molecular basis for the high infectiousness of SARS-CoV-2.

Source:https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/26/7/20-0282_article?deliveryName=USCDC_333-DM25287

name: Moderator - Nick
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph:  "Coronavirus and the Potential for Destruction or Not?" by Jude of Pasadena, CA, “The Dangerous Range of Disease” by Gracie of Western Guilford High School in Greensboro, NC, “Coronavirus Chaos” by Lauren of Academy of Saint Elizabeth in Morristown, NJ, “Can the Coronavirus Go Up Against These Other Big Dog Diseases?” by Chanse of Academy for Software Engineering, New York City, and “Frequent and Fatal Diseases“ by Kiersten of St. John the Apostle School, Clark, NJ,
You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, Feb. 27 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and a few Stat Nuggets.
The next graph will be released in two days -- Friday, Feb. 28, with moderation on Wednesday, March 4.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to “What's Going On In This Graph?”  The topic --  voter opinion polls on hot topics.

name: Grace R
comment info: This graph shows how infectious certain diseases are and the mortality rates of these diseases, including coronavirus. Diseases graphed higher up have a greater mortality rate and diseases graphed farther right are more infectious. The graph shows diseases like the bird flu, ebola, and MERS to be highly fatal and the common cold and the chickenpox to be relatively harmless. It also shows MERS, the bird flu, and the seasonal flu to be uninfectious, but the chickenpox and measles to be very infectious. The graph represents the data for coronavirus in a red box, as there is probably not enough data to condense the disease into a single point. The fatality rate for coronavirus is between .1% and around 5%, and each sick person infects between 1 and 3 people. I wonder when scientists will have enough data to label coronavirus in a more accurate manner, and how many people total were infected by each disease. One possible title for this graph could be "Statistics on Infectious Diseases."

1) I noticed that the new coronavirus occupies a large volume on the graph, ranging from about 1-4% fatality rate. name: Sean Hession
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Headline: Chinese Response to Coronavirus Excessive?
     In this graph, I notice that the new coronavirus has a higher possible infectivity and higher amount of people infected by each sick person than some other serious diseases. It is deadlier than polio and more infectious than the common cold. However, it is less deadly than ebola, and smallpox and less infectious than measles and smallpox. I also notice that there is no set number for fatality rate or infection rate. Instead there is a red highlighted zone where it is thought to be. This shows how little data there still is on this virus. The fact that the zone of uncertainty places the death rate at anywhere from .1% to almost 5% and the infection rate from a little over 1 to almost 3 proves that more research should be done. 
         Due to the uncertainty about this virus, China has imposed a lockdown in Wuhan and surrounding areas to avoid spreading the virus. However, seeing that it is possible that the fatality rate is as low as .1% and that it is less deadly and infectious than most serious diseases makes me wonder if it is worth quarantining entire regions and restricting travel for millions. While there should still be quarantine for those confirmed infected and treatments should be a priority, perhaps the response, which had some adverse effects, like trapping vacationing foreigners in China, was too great. Hopefully, the spread of the coronavirus will soon be slowed and travel to China will be reopened.

name: Charlotte Saxton
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
A New Outbreak

I notice that this graph is showing well known diseases and their fatality rates. Some are obviously 0% fatality rate, like the common cold and chickenpox, while others, like ebola and smallpox, are way higher up. The thing that stands out the most in this graph is the Coronavirus, which is a current disease, so it’s fatality rate has not been determined yet. Because of the uncertainty, it’s data is just in a red box with an estimate of the rate. I wonder how much the rate will grow, and what will happen with the virus.

name: Avery Hodges
comment info:
Severe Sicknesses

The first thing I saw in this graph was the large red box representing the coronavirus on the right side of the graph. Then, after taking a closer look, I saw the small yellow dots that represented several other diseases. I was surprised to see many diseases higher up on the scale of fatality rate than the coronavirus, but it is also a very new thing, so I'm sure it's just getting started. But I wonder, why is the coronavirus in a large red box instead of a small yellow dot like the rest? Perhaps it is because there is little known about the virus, but I'd be interested to have more information.
